source_description: Complete guide to formatting journal article citations in APA 7th edition, including DOIs, volume numbers, and page ranges.
quick_reference_template: Author, A. A. (Year). Title of article in sentence case. *Journal Name in Title Case, Volume*(Issue), pages. https://doi.org/xxxxx
basic_format_explanation: Journal articles follow a consistent format in APA 7th edition. The article title uses sentence case (only first word and proper nouns capitalized), while the journal name uses title case and italics. Volume numbers are italicized, but issue numbers are not in parentheses. DOIs are formatted as URLs rather than with the 'doi:' prefix.
key_elements: Journal name in italics, title case

required_elements.name: Author(s)
required_elements.description: Last name followed by first and middle initials. Maximum 20 authors listed.

required_elements.name: Publication Year
required_elements.description: Year in parentheses, followed by a period.

required_elements.name: Article Title
required_elements.description: Title in sentence case, ending with a period.

required_elements.name: Journal Name
required_elements.description: Full journal name in title case and italics.

required_elements.name: DOI
required_elements.description: Digital Object Identifier formatted as URL.

optional_elements.name: Issue Number
optional_elements.description: Include when journal uses issue numbering and each issue starts at page 1.

optional_elements.name: Article Number
optional_elements.description: Use instead of page range when journal uses article numbering.

missing_elements_guidance: If no DOI is available, include the journal homepage URL. If no URL is available, end citation after page range.

reference_examples.citation: Smith, J. K., & Johnson, L. M. (2023). The impact of artificial intelligence on academic research integrity. *Journal of Scholarly Publishing, 54*(2), 123-145. https://doi.org/10.1353/jsp.2023.0012

breakdown.value: Smith, J. K., & Johnson, L. M.
The impact of artificial intelligence on academic research integrity.

reference_examples.citation: Williams, R. T. (2022). Climate change adaptation strategies in coastal communities. *Environmental Policy Review, 18*(3), 45-67.

reference_examples.special_note: Use 'in press' if article accepted but not yet published.
reference_examples.citation: Anderson, P. R., & Davis, M. K. (2024). Machine learning applications in psychological assessment. *Clinical Psychology Review*. Advance online publication. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cpr.2024.102345

in_text_guidelines: In-text citations for journal articles include the author(s) and year. For two authors, include both names. For three or more authors, include the first author followed by 'et al.' Use narrative format (Author, Year) when the author is part of your sentence, or parenthetical format (Author, Year) at the end of the sentence.
parenthetical_examples: Recent research supports this conclusion (Smith & Johnson, 2023).
Previous studies have shown conflicting results (Williams, 2022).
multiple_authors_guidance: Two authors: List both names. Three or more authors: Use first author's name followed by 'et al.' in all citations (APA 7 simplified this from APA 6).
special_cases_guidance: No author: Use title in place of author. No date: Use 'n.d.' Organization as author: Use organization name. Multiple works by same author: List in chronological order.
step_by_step_instructions: 1. **Identify the Author(s)**: List all authors up to 20. Format as Last Name, F. M. 2. **Find the Publication Year**: Locate the year in parentheses after author names. 3. **Copy the Article Title**: Use exact title, capitalizing only first word and proper nouns. 4. **Locate Journal Information**: Find the full journal name, volume, issue, and page numbers. 5. **Find the DOI**: Look for the DOI, usually on the first page or in database record. 6. **Format Everything**: Apply proper italics, punctuation, and spacing according to APA format. 7. **Double-Check**: Verify all elements are present and correctly formatted.
pro_tip: Save time by using citation management software like Zotero or EndNote, but always double-check the formatting against APA 7 guidelines.

common_errors.wrong_example: Smith, J. (2023). The Impact Of Artificial Intelligence On Research. *Journal of Science, 15*(2), 123-145.
common_errors.correct_example: Smith, J. (2023). The impact of artificial intelligence on research. *Journal of Science, 15*(2), 123-145.
common_errors.why_it_happens: Students often apply title case to article titles instead of sentence case as required by APA 7.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Change article title to sentence case: capitalize only the first word, first word after colon, and proper nouns.

common_errors.wrong_example: Johnson, L. (2022). Climate policy implications. *Environmental Studies, 8*(1), 23-34. doi:10.1234/env.2022.001
common_errors.correct_example: Johnson, L. (2022). Climate policy implications. *Environmental Studies, 8*(1), 23-34. https://doi.org/10.1234/env.2022.001
common_errors.why_it_happens: APA 6 used 'doi:' prefix, but APA 7 requires DOIs formatted as clickable URLs.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Change 'doi:' prefix to 'https://doi.org/' to create a clickable link.

validation_checklist: Author names formatted as Last, F. M.
Publication year in parentheses with period
Article title in sentence case with period
Journal name in italics and title case
All periods and commas in correct places
quick_validation_tip: Read the citation aloud. It should flow naturally with proper pauses at punctuation marks.
red_flags: Article title has title case capitalization
DOI uses 'doi:' prefix instead of URL format
Missing italics for journal name or volume
Using hyphens instead of en-dashes for page ranges

special_cases.title: Article with Article Number
special_cases.when_applies: When journal uses article numbering instead of page ranges
special_cases.formatting: Use 'Article' followed by the number instead of page range
special_cases.example: Thompson, K. (2023). Data privacy in healthcare research. *Medical Ethics Journal, 12*(1), Article 3. https://doi.org/10.1111/medj.2023.3

faq.question: How do I cite a journal article with more than 20 authors?
faq.answer: List the first 19 authors, insert an ellipsis (...), then list the final author. For example: Smith, J., Johnson, K., Williams, M., ... Brown, T. (2023).
faq.example: Smith, J., Johnson, K., Williams, M., Davis, R., ... Brown, T. (2023). Research methods overview. *Psychology Journal, 45*(2), 123-145.

faq.question: What if I can't find the DOI for a journal article?
faq.answer: First, search Crossref.org using the article title and author. If still no DOI found, include the journal's homepage URL. If the article is from a print-only journal, end the citation after the page range.

faq.question: Do I need to include database names in journal article citations?
faq.answer: Generally no, unless the article is from an exclusive database that's the only way to access it. In most cases, use DOI or journal URL instead.

expert_tips.title: Use Crossref for DOI Verification
expert_tips.content: Always verify DOIs through Crossref.org. This ensures accuracy and helps you spot fake or incorrect DOIs that sometimes appear in database records.

expert_tips.title: Maintain a DOI Log
expert_tips.content: Keep a spreadsheet of DOIs for articles you frequently cite. This saves time and ensures consistency across your papers.

best_practice_summary: Always verify journal article information against the original source rather than relying solely on database records, which can contain formatting errors.
bottom_line_summary: Journal article citations require attention to detail: proper author formatting, sentence case for titles, correct italicization, and accurate DOI formatting. Master these elements and you'll handle most academic citations confidently.
three_important_rules: Article titles use sentence case (not title case)
Volume numbers are italicized, issue numbers are in parentheses
DOIs are formatted as clickable URLs (https://doi.org/...)
